title: Is It Always My Fault? The Illusion of Omnipotence
description: This article explores the psychological phenomenon of personalization—the belief that you are the cause of everything that happens around you. It explains how this thinking style works and how it leads to stress, anxiety, low self-esteem, and difficulties in relationships. The article also looks at where this belief comes from, starting with childhood experiences and cultural influences, and offers recommendations for overcoming personalization and freeing yourself from unnecessary guilt.

texts: In any situation, whatever the outcome, it must somehow be my doing.

Missed the train — I must have taken too long getting ready. People sitting across from me on the subway are laughing — they must be laughing at me. My partner is in a bad mood — I must have done something wrong.
Does that sound familiar?
If yes, then you may be dealing with a belief in your own omnipotence.
Every one of us encounters personalization to some degree.
It is a subtle psychological trap that makes you feel like the center of the universe and pushes you to take responsibility for much of what happens around you.

You are convinced that people’s reactions are always about you, that their actions, thoughts, and feelings are entirely shaped by what you do, even though in reality these things are not under your control.
Yet you keep tormenting yourself, judging yourself, and carrying a heavy sense of guilt.
Paradoxically, this belief in your own omnipotence and limitless power actually constrains you, fueling anxiety and making you less effective.
How does personalization show up?
“It’s all because of me”: you tend to believe that everything that happens in life is the result of your own actions. It does not matter whether it is good or bad — you take full responsibility.
“Everything revolves around me”: you are convinced that others are constantly thinking about you, talking about you, and noticing every single mistake and flaw.
“It’s my fault”: a sense of guilt becomes your constant companion, no matter what actually caused the situation.
For example:

Imagine you walk into a store and the cashier speaks to you rudely. Instead of thinking that they might be having a bad day or are simply rude, you start blaming yourself: “I must have said or done something wrong.”
You meet up with friends, and they invite someone you do not like. You decide they did it on purpose to show that you are not welcome and that they do not really want to spend time with you.
“If they are not answering my call, it means they are offended by something I did.”
These teenagers are laughing and exchanging glances — they must be talking about me.

With this thinking style, it does not really matter who is actually responsible — it always feels like you are. What do you think this leads to? Unsurprisingly, to stress, apathy, anxiety, problems with self-esteem, and even depression.
Why is personalization harmful?
Excessive self-criticism: people may become overly self-critical and feel guilty about events that were never really under their control.
Stress and anxiety: the constant sense that “everything is my fault” creates chronic stress and anxiety.
Relationship problems: people who tend to personalize may misinterpret others’ behavior, feel hurt, and damage relationships.
Distorted view of reality: like any irrational belief, personalization misleads you, keeps you from seeing the bigger picture, and makes you overlook objective facts and circumstances.
Low self-esteem: when you keep blaming yourself for everything, you slowly undermine your confidence and self-worth.
Victim position: some people unconsciously try to harm or punish themselves for imagined wrongdoings. They may even allow others to treat them disrespectfully.

quote.text: Guilt almost inevitably gives rise to a script of punishment, and your conscious mind may not even know it is happening.
quote.author: Vadim Zeland

texts: Where does personalization come from?
This type of belief begins to form in childhood.
It is well known that children’s thinking is egocentric — a child sincerely believes they are the cause of everything that happens around them.
For a three- or four-year-old, it is completely normal to think that the sun rises because they woke up and sets because it is time for them to go to bed.
However, many adults continue to use elements of this egocentric thinking in everyday life.
Family or social pressure can push someone to feel responsible for other people’s well-being. For example, a child who has to take care of their parents from an early age.
Low self-esteem can be both a consequence and a cause of these beliefs.
People with low self-esteem are often prone to personalization. They may believe they do not deserve to be treated well and therefore attribute negative events to their own actions or flaws.

Traumatic experiences in the past can also contribute to personalization. In early childhood, thinking is especially vulnerable to distortions, and a child can easily come to believe that everything depends on them.
For example, if someone often heard from their parents, “It’s all your fault,” or “You never do anything right,” they may carry this label for life, blaming themselves for every negative event.
In some cultures, people are encouraged to take responsibility for everything that happens around them. This can make them more prone to personalization, even when they are not actually at fault.
Whatever the reasons behind these beliefs, we can change our thinking at any point in life if we are motivated to do so.
In the next chapter, as usual, we will look at key recommendations for working with the belief in your own omnipotence.

quote.text: You cannot blame yourself for everything unless you secretly believe you are all-powerful.
quote.author: Mikhail Bulgakov

exercise.title: The Escape from the Trap of “It’s All My Fault”
exercise.description: The article examines the phenomenon of personalization—the tendency to perceive events as personally related to oneself. It discusses methods to reduce the negative consequences of such thinking, including self-observation and situational analysis. The author offers practical advice and exercises to improve mental well-being and free oneself from unnecessary guilt.

texts: Sometimes people mistakenly refer to the belief in personalization as “megalomania”.

However, this does not necessarily indicate illusions of grandeur, but rather reflects a worldview in which a person prone to personalization places themselves at the center of the universe: all events seem personally connected to them.
Internally, this is not experienced as a sense of immense power or strength, but as constant pressure, attention from others, and hidden hostility.
To overcome this harmful style of thinking, it’s important to identify the true causes of the problems that have arisen.
Instead of blaming yourself for things that are beyond your control and, consequently, feeling guilty towards the entire world, focus on analyzing the situation.

Start with self-observation. The first step to reducing personalization is awareness, as with any other irrational thinking. Pay close attention to your thoughts and reactions to events. Notice when you tend to take responsibility for something that is actually beyond your control.

Then, try to identify other factors that could have influenced the situation for which you took responsibility. For example: “Is it really true that I am solely to blame for this argument? What other factors and circumstances could have played a role?”

Consider possible reasons for other people’s behavior that are unrelated to your actions. Try to put yourself in their shoes and understand what might have influenced their reaction. For example, what else could have caused their mood or behavior?

quote.text: Everything we hear is an opinion, not a fact. Everything we see is a perspective, not the truth.
quote.author: Marcus Aurelius

texts: Use the following questions for analysis:
Do I need to blame myself for what happened?
Was I in a position to control this?
Am I really responsible for everything? Or just part of the problem? Which part exactly?
What other reasons might there be for this problem?
Example:

Imagine a situation: you arrive at work, and your colleague doesn’t greet you. Immediately, a thought arises: “I did something wrong. It seems she doesn’t like me. Maybe I said something wrong yesterday, or I didn’t greet her, and now she’s holding it against me.”
Analyze your thoughts using the above questions and write down alternative rational responses:
Perhaps she didn’t greet me because she didn’t sleep well, simply forgot, was lost in thought, or greeted me earlier, and I didn’t notice.

Most likely, her possible bad state and the fact that she didn’t greet me have nothing to do with my behavior. I can only prove otherwise if I ask her directly. The most likely explanation: she didn’t sleep well, something happened in the morning, or she simply forgot.

I’m not sure if she was sad, but even if she was, there are many reasons for her state that may have nothing to do with me. Even if she is upset because of me, she should tell me about it; otherwise, I can’t understand the situation for sure.
Since I don’t know for certain whether the reason is related to my actions, I will not feel guilty about it.
Remember that we cannot control everything in life. Sometimes we just need to accept what happens and not try to explain everything through our own mistakes.

quote.text: People are not disturbed by things, but by their views on them.
quote.author: Epictetus

texts: You can also use the following exercises to work on your belief:
Applying an External Perspective

Imagine a friend tells you that his colleague didn’t greet him in the morning. How would you react? What would you say to him? What advice would you give? This will help you distance yourself from your own emotions and look at the situation more objectively.
Continue the phrase “if I were really...”
Try to finish the following sentence: “If I were really responsible for this, it would mean that...”

For example: “If I were really responsible for the project’s failure, it would mean that I could control all the participants and prevent any mistakes.” But in reality, many factors are beyond your control.
“If I were really responsible for my friend being upset with me, it would mean that I could read his mind and guess his desires.” But that is impossible.
Completing the “if I were really...” phrase will help you analyze your responsibility and realize that you can’t always control everything that happens.
By using these simple techniques, you can rid yourself of negative thoughts and free yourself from the feeling that you are responsible for everything.

Remember that you are not the center of the universe and don’t have to be responsible for all the events around you. It’s better to focus your energy on solving problems and creating a happier and more harmonious life.
